content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Search for a hotel in Hokkaido for the period March 1 to March 7, 2024, with a rating of 9+, check out its user reviews, which categories are greater than 9 and which are less than 9?  Please interact with https://www.booking.com/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To start searching for a hotel in Hokkaido, I need to enter "Hokkaido" as the destination in the textbox for "Where are you going?" before setting the check-in and check-out dates.
Action: Type [14]; Hokkaido
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is currently set to September and October 2025. I need to search for availability from March 1 to March 7, 2024, which means I must move the calendar back to the correct year and month. This will likely involve clicking a "previous month" button, which should appear somewhere near the top of the calendar. Since only the "Next month" button (18) is visible, I should scroll up to try to find the previous month button or further navigation options.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is still showing dates in 2025, and only the "Next month" button (18) is visible, which will not help in reaching March 2024. There is likely a "Previous month" button available either offscreen or at the edge of the calendar that needs to be revealed for navigation to earlier dates.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; left
Confidence: 0.75
Completion: 0.15
The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.

Thought: The only way to proceed to earlier months is to look for a "Previous month" button or navigation option that might be to the left or above the calendar, which could be revealed by scrolling up or left. Since scrolling left isn't an option, I should try clicking around the calendar area to possibly reveal more navigation options for previous months.
Action: Scroll [WINDOW]; up
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar still only displays September and October 2025, and the "Next month" button (18) is the only navigation visible. Scrolling has not revealed any "Previous month" button. Perhaps clicking the "Check-in date — Check-out date" button (15) will reopen or reset the calendar and bring me to the current date or allow me to select an earlier month more efficiently.
Action: Click [15]
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar popup has closed and the search results page is displayed for Hokkaido, but the dates have not been set to March 1-7, 2024 (search results defaulted to unspecified dates). I need to open the date picker again to select the correct check-in/check-out range.
Action: Click [15]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.18
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar has reopened, but it still displays only future months (September and October 2025), with only the "Next month" (18) button available for navigation. I need to get to March 2024, so I should look for a way to access earlier months—but since no previous button is visible, a possible solution is clicking the "Calendar" button (16) to try to reset the calendar view or reveal more navigation options.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.75
Completion: 0.18
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is still only showing September and October 2025, with only the "Next month" (18) button available for navigation. There's no visible way to go to a previous month or to quickly access an earlier year. Since none of the usual actions reset the calendar, it looks like progressing from September 2025 to March 2024 could require an excessive amount of clicking "Next month" in reverse, but since only a "Next month" button is visible, I am unable to reach earlier dates. I need to review for any overlooked options, such as reopening the calendar or switching modes ("I'm flexible"), or perhaps refreshing the filters and starting over. I'll try clicking the "I'm flexible" button (17) to check if it offers a way back to regular date selection or quick year navigation.
Action: Click [17]
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.18
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "I'm flexible" mode has appeared, showing options to pick months, but all months currently visible are in late 2025 and early 2026. There is no visible way to directly jump to earlier years or months, such as March 2024. There also may be further navigation or options to get to 2024 if I exit the flexible date mode. Returning to the regular calendar picker by clicking "Calendar" (16) might reset to the normal month-by-month interface, where I could look more closely for any way to get to 2024.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar is still stuck on September and October 2025 without showing any option to go to previous months or years. The only navigational button visible is "Next month" (18), and there doesn't appear to be a way to scroll back to 2024 or set an earlier date. This might be a bug or limitation with the current interface state. Trying to reset the search by clicking the close button (14) or reopening the calendar might help.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.22
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar was closed and the "Where are you going?" search textbox (13) has been reset. Hokkaido is no longer set as the destination, so to continue searching for a hotel in Hokkaido, I need to re-enter "Hokkaido" in the destination textbox.
Action: Type [13]; Hokkaido
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.24
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination "Hokkaido" has been entered, and the calendar popup for check-in/out dates is visible again, still showing September and October 2025. The "Next month" (18) button is the only navigation option. No "Previous month" or "jump to year" buttons are visible. Because the calendar remains stuck in the future and there is no obvious way to go back, it might help to reset or refresh the check-in date selection by clicking outside the calendar or trying the calendar-related buttons again.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.25
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar remains stuck on September and October 2025 with only the "Next month" (18) button for navigation. All activities so far to reset or change the year have failed. Since direct navigation isn’t possible, I should try to completely close this calendar popup and start the date selection process from scratch. The close button should be the "X" at [14].
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.28
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The recent search "Hokkaido" is listed and can be quickly reselected. The date and traveler/room fields are empty and need to be filled next after destination selection. By clicking [14] ("Hokkaido 2 adults"), I can efficiently set the destination to Hokkaido, as required.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar popup is again stuck in September and October 2025, with only the "Next month" (18) button visible. No option for selecting an earlier year/month or resetting the calendar to 2024 is present. Previous attempts at closing/reopening did not help. Given this dead end, it may be more effective to try another search workflow—such as entering March 1 to March 7, 2024, directly into the date field if allowed, or refreshing the home page. The only actionable calendar buttons remain: "Calendar" (16) and "I'm flexible" (17). Clicking "I'm flexible" may provide an alternate date selection experience or possibly offer a way to jump to earlier dates.
Action: Click [17]
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.32
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "I'm flexible" date picker is open. I need to book for exactly one week, from March 1 to March 7, 2024. Since current month/year options shown are from late 2025 to early 2026, I need to look for a way to access earlier dates. This UI does not show navigation for earlier years. There might be an option if I press "Select dates" (44) to switch back to or reset the classic calendar mode, potentially allowing earlier date selection.
Action: Click [44]
Confidence: 0.8
Completion: 0.34
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "I'm flexible" interface remains open, still only offering month selection in 2025 and 2026, which does not meet the requirement for March 2024. Clicking "Select dates" (44) didn't change the interface. Returning to the standard calendar interface by clicking "Calendar" (16) might provide the option to navigate back, reset, or fix the date picker.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.36

Thought: The calendar is still stuck on September and October 2025, and there is only a "Next month" button (18) visible, but no way to go back to earlier years or months from the interface. There is no "Previous month" button, and none of the current workflows bring me to 2024. This suggests a possible UI issue or a limitation that cannot be bypassed with the current screen; I should consider restarting by clearing the dates completely and trying a fresh destination/dates entry. Clicking the "Check-in date — Check-out date" button (15) might reset the calendar or let me try entering new dates.
Action: Click [15]
Confidence: 0.7
Completion: 0.37

Previously tried pathways haven't resolved the issue. I need to find any way to reset the date picker or select earlier years and months. Since the "Exact dates" option (89) is visible at the bottom of the calendar, clicking it may give the ability to specify dates directly or provide more precise navigation and might reveal a way to jump to March 2024.
